metadata.title: Synthesis of sustainable chemicals and fuels from biomass derivatives using homogeneous ruthenium catalysts

República 498, Santiago, Chile Facultad de Ciencias Exactas Departamento de Ciencias Químicas Universidad Andrés Bello Av. República 498 Santiago Chile cFacultad de Ciencias Exactas, Departamento de Ciencias Químicas, Universidad Andrés Bello, Av. República 498, Santiago, Chile ⁎ Corresponding authors. This work describes the synthesis and evaluation as catalysts of two ruthenium(II) complexes, RuC1 and RuC2, containing NPN ligands=(N-(phenyl(pyridin-2-ylamino)phosphino)pyridin-2-amine and 2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino)methyl)pyridine, respectively) for furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation. The catalysts displayed exceptional activity under mild conditions (180 °C, 40 bar H2) achieving over 98 % conversion and 98–99 % selectivity towards furfuryl alcohol (from furfural) and bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (from hydroxymethylfurfural) within 30 min, using a substrate-catalyst ratio of 3000:1. Remarkably, the catalysts maintained their efficacy even at a tenfold higher substrate loading (10,000:1), albeit with extended reaction times (3 and 4 h for furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural, respectively). Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were impressive, reaching 3920 h−1 and 3200 h−1 for furfural hydrogenation with the catalyst RuC1 and RuC2, respectively. Similarly, TOFs for hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation were 2450 h−1 and 2475 h−1 for RuC1 and RuC2, respectively. Notably, the catalysts exhibited excellent stability under reaction conditions. These findings demonstrate the promising potential of RuC1 and RuC2 for efficient hydrogenation of biomass-derived furans, offering a sustainable approach for the production of valuable bio-based chemicals. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Homogeneous catalysis Valorization of biomass Ruthenium catalyst NPN Ligands Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past decade, there has been significant development in the generation of compounds from renewable sources. These compounds can replace or complement those derived from fossil fuels. Three general classes of feedstocks derived from biomass are appropriate for producing renewable fuels, namely, starch, triglyceride (oils), and lignocellulose. The valorization of biomass is a crucial objective in both academia and industry. The former aims to generate knowledge for transforming biomass, while the latter aims to obtain applied technology for biomass byproducts [1–3] furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural are versatile platform compounds derived from lignocellulosic biomass. Various catalytic reactions can produce biofuels, fuel additives, renewable chemicals, furanic compounds, and petrochemicals [1]. The most common reactions used in these transformations are hydrogenation, etherification, and oligomerization in tandem with hydrogenation, followed by esterification [2,3]. One of the most successful reactions for extracting biofuels and renewable chemical products is the catalytic transformation of furfural by hydrogenation, which has successfully employed both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. For instance, researchers have studied Cu2Cr2O5, Cu/SiO2, Cu/Carbon, Cu/MgO, and CuCa/SiO2 as catalysts in the synthesis of furfuryl alcohol via heterogeneous hydrogenation, resulting in high conversions and variable selectivity [2–16]. In the hydrogenation of furfural, the reaction conditions and the solvent used for the catalytic reaction are crucial. Typically, using 2-propanol as the solvent yields the best results [1–10]. The successful hydrogenation of furfural has been studied using homogeneous catalysts, coordination complexes, and organometallic compounds of Ir(I) and Ru(II), as explored in this reaction. The hydrogenation of furfural and other substrates was extensively studied by our group using molecular hydrogen or hydrogen transfer reactions. The obtained results showed a high conversion to furfuryl alcohol with a selectivity of 100 % [16–22]. Our group conducted a study that demonstrated high conversions and selectivity's in the hydrogenation of furfural in short reaction times (30 min) using high substrate concentration over a substrate/catalyst ratio of 3000/1 with Ru(II) compounds and phosphorus-nitrogen (PN) ligands [17]. Hydroxymethylfurfural is a derivative of biomass that has been studied in various catalytic transformations to tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol, bis(hydroxymethyl)furan and levulinic acid. The hydrogenation of this derivative has been studied using both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. For instance, ruthenium complexes containing phosphine ligands have reported conversions ranging from 1 % to 71 % to bis(hydroxymethyl)furan. However, the selectivity's was poor due to the formation of tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol or levulinic acid as secondary products [23]. The hydrogenation of hydroxymethylfurfural using Pd/Al2O3 catalyst resulted in the formation of cis- and trans-tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol, with a ratio of 9:1 in favor of the cis isomer [24]. Ruthenium catalysts supported by active carbon have been reported to convert over 71 % to 2,5 dimethylfurane, but with a selectivity of only around 70 % [25]. Bimetallic catalysts, such as PtCo@HCS-based and CuRu/C, have reported a high conversion of hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5 dimethylfurane with selectivities around 61 % at 180 °C after 2 h of reaction. Other reported of hydrogenation of biomass derivatives has been studied using heterogeneous Ni/Al2O3 and CuAl2O3 catalysts. After 60 min of reaction, conversion rates between 40 % and 60 % were achieved with variable selectivities between 100 % and 60 % for furfuryl alcohol [26–33]. Cu nanowire, CuCaAlO CuZnO, and CuCeO2 have also been studied for this reaction, achieving conversions over 90 %, However, high temperatures are required, and selectivity varies between 8 and 94 % [34–37]. Heterogeneous catalysts, such as Pd/SiO2, Pd-Ir/SiO2, Pd-Ru/SiO2, Pd-Rh/SiO2, and Pd-Pt/SiO2, have been successfully used for the hydrogenation of hydroxymethylfurfural. The reported conversions range from 2 % to 67 %, except for the Pd−Ir/SiO2 catalyst, which achieved a conversion of 99 % but required a reaction time 12 times longer than the catalysts studied in this work. The Pd-Ir/SiO2 catalyst was studied as catalyst in furfural hydrogenation requires 6 h of reaction time to convert 99 % with a selectivity of 94 % [36]. The results indicate that homogeneous catalysts can be used as an alternative for the hydrogenation of furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural due to their ability to achieve high conversion and selectivity’ with very low catalyst loadings. Furthermore, homogeneous catalysts are less sensitive to changes in the reaction solvent, unlike heterogeneous catalysts, which can affect the catalytic reaction's selectivity [33]. On the other hand, homogeneous ruthenium and iridium catalysts have been successfully studied in biomass valorization by hydrogenation of furfural. However, the substrate concentrations used were low. Ruthenium complexes showed activities between 90 %−99 % in furfural hydrogenation but the reaction required a longer reaction time with a low substrate/catalyst ratio. Iridium half-sandwich complexes showed a conversion rate between 90 % and 96 %, but the reaction also required an extended reaction time [36–39]. The results show that the reaction selectivity is highly dependent on the reaction conditions and catalysts studied. According to the report on the hydrogenation of biomass byproducts, making the hydrogenation of furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural better could help the industry in catalytic ways. Therefore, it is worthwhile to study this reaction [36–43]. The objective of this study is to evaluate the catalytic activity of two homogeneous catalysts in the hydrogenation of biomass derivatives. These ruthenium complexes have in their structure a nitrogen-phosphorus-nitrogen (NPN) ligand. Previous studies have shown that these ligands stabilize ruthenium under catalytic conditions, preventing the catalyst's decomposition [17–19]. Both ligands provide similar electronic and steric properties to the metal. The selected ligands contain a polypyridine fragment and a phosphine fragment linked by a -CH2- or a -NH- group. Previous work suggest that the -NH- group could assists in the activation of the molecular hydrogen to form the metal hydride [19,21]. This study reports the synthesis and characterization of two complexes type Ru(NPN)PPh3Cl2 with NPN = N-(phenyl(pyridin-2-ylamino)phosphino)pyridin-2-amine and 2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino)methyl)pyridine (Fig. 1 ). These complexes were studied as catalysts in the furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation. The results showed that the catalysts were highly active in these catalytic reactions using a substrate/catalyst ratio 10,000/1. The complexes RuC1 and RuC2 archive 96 % and 98 % of conversion with high selectivity's to furfuryl alcohol after 3 h of reaction time. On the other hand, the complexes RuC1 and RuC2 archive 98 % and 99 % of conversion with high selectivity's to bis(hydroxymethyl)furan after 4 h of reaction time. Both catalytic reactions show selectivity's over 98 % for the desired product. 2 Experimental section The ligands and catalysts were synthesized using the protocol previously reported by our group [21]. The catalytic reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatographic (GC) and confirmed by GC–MS. The ligands and complexes were characterized by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) using hydrogen nucleus (1H NMR) and phosphorus nucleus (31P-NMR). The structure of the complexes was confirmed by elemental analysis or X-ray diffraction. The complex Ru(NPN)PPh3Cl2 and the ligands N-(phenyl(pyridin-2-ylamino)phosphino)pyridin-2-amine were previously reported by our group, and the previous synthesis protocol was used without modification [19–21]. The ligand 2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino) methyl)pyridine was synthesized using the protocol reported by Kermagoret et al. with modifications [44]. 2.1 Synthesis of ligand (2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino) methyl)pyridine) In a Schlenk tube a solution of n-BuLi (mmol, 2 M in hexane) was added dropwise to a solution of 2-picoline (2.00 g, 21,5 mmol) in 15 mL of dry THF at −78 °C. After further stirring for 2 h at −78 °C, chlorotrimethylsilane (2,3 g, 21,5 mmol) was added dropwise to the solution. The mixture was allowed to reach room temperature overnight, and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. The pure intermediate 2-[(trimethylsilyl)methyl]pyridine was obtained by distilling the liquid residue under reduced pressure. The yield was 1.59 g (10.0 mmol, 45 %). Next, 2-[(trimethylsilyl)methyl]pyridine (1.59 g, 10.0 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of dry THF cooled to −78 °C, and PPhCl2 (0.90 g, 5.0 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was allowed to reach room temperature overnight. The solvents were evaporated under reduced pressure to obtain an orange oil with a yield of 1.34 g (4.58 mmol, 47 %). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.43 – 8.35 (m, 2H) and 7.45 – 7.33 (m, 4H) to 7.22 (d, J = 4.7 Hz, 3H), 6.94 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 4H), and 3.32 (dd, J = 33.1, 13.4 Hz, 4H). The 31P-NMR (162 MHz, CDCl3) δ −13.83 (s). 2.2 Synthesis of complex In a Schlenk tube equipped with a condenser, RuCl2(PPh3)3 (4.4 g, 4.6 mmol) was dissolved in toluene (20 mL) and refluxed for 10 min under stirring. Then, ligand 2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino)methyl)pyridine (1.3 g, 4.6 mmol) was added, and the mixture was refluxed for 4 h until a yellow powder was obtained. The solvent was filtrated, the resulting solid was washed with Et2O and dried under vacuum to yield the compound. The nuclear magnetic resonance spectrum was recorded at 300 MHz in CDCl3. The chemical shifts (δ) of the peaks were as follows: 10.29 (d, J = 5.6 Hz, 1H), 9.26 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 7.84 – 6.80 (m, 31H), 6.38 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 1H), 4.18 (dd, J = 17.9, 9.9 Hz, 1H), 3.68 – 3.47 (m, 3H). The 31P-NMR spectrum (121 MHz, CDCl3) showed peaks at δ 68.13 (d, J = 32.5 Hz) and 45.90 (d, J = 32.4 Hz). 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic hydrogenation of furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural (Fig. 2 ) was conducted in a 20 mL stainless-steel autoclave (batch reactor system). A typical reaction process is described as follows: furfural or hydroxymethylfurfural was charge, fallowed PPh3 (0.0137 mmol) and catalyst (0.0137 mmol; 10 mg) in 2-propanol (10 mL) were sealed in the autoclave. The reactor was first purged three times and then pressurized with hydrogen. 2.4 Crystal structure determination and refinement Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis of complex Ru(NPN)(PPh3)Cl2 with NPN = 2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino)methyl)pyridine were obtained by slow evaporation of a saturated solution as described in the synthetic part (see Scheme 1 ). The crystal structure was determined by X-ray diffraction at room temperature. Data collection was done on a SMART CCD diffractometer using ϖ scans as collection strategy. Data sets were reduced using SAINT [45], while the structure was solved by the Patterson method and then completed by difference Fourier synthesis. Refinement by least-squares were done by using SHELXL [46,47]. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS [45]. Crystal data, data collection and structure refinement details are summarized in Table 1 . The H-atoms positions were calculated after each cycle of refinement using a riding model, with C—H distances equal to 0.93 and Uiso(H) = 1.2 Ueq parent. 3 Result and discussion Table 1 summarizes the catalytic activity of the studied catalysts in furfural hydrogenation, optimizing the use of acid as a co-catalyst. While acid promotes conversion (Table 1 entries 3 & 4), the type of acid appears to have minimal influence. This suggests the primary role of acid is hydrogen activation for Ru-H formation [17]. Notably, RuC1 and RuC2 exhibit good activity without acid (Table 1, entries 1 & 2), achieving 57 % and 83 % conversion at 120 °C, respectively). Formic acid may be a more suitable alternative since it is renewable and decomposes into CO2 + H2 during the process, which could contribute to the hydrogenation process. However, excessive acid usage can be detrimental (entry 3). High acid concentrations might decompose the catalyst or promote unwanted side reactions, leading to selectivity loss. Additionally, the positive effect of acid diminishes with increasing substrate loading (entry 4 vs. entries 8). This implies that acid availability becomes limiting at higher substrate concentrations. Despite the promising results, increasing the substrate/catalyst ratio reduces the effect of acid as a co-catalyst. The catalytic reaction does not improve with increased substrate concentrations using the same acid concentration. The catalyst archive revealed that entries 9 and 10 had 56 % and 26 % conversion rates, respectively, when the substrate/catalyst ratio was 3000/1. Variables such as temperature and pressure were investigated to enhance the reaction's conversion rate. Table 2 demonstrates the significant impact of temperature on furfural hydrogenation. Compared to reactions at 120 °C (Table 1), increasing the temperature to 150 °C with RuC1 and RuC2 catalysts (entries 3 & 6) led to a dramatic improvement in conversion, reaching near-complete conversion (100 % and 93 % respectively) within just 1 h at a 3000/1 substrate/catalyst ratio. Interestingly, the addition of an acid co-catalyst at 150 °C (entries 2 & 7) showed no significant improvement compared to reactions without acid (entries 3 & 6). This suggests that the higher temperature effectively promotes hydrogen activation, potentially negating the need for additional acid-mediated activation. We conducted studies to optimize acid usage, molecular hydrogen pressure, and reaction time based on the impact of temperature on the furfural hydrogenation reaction. Table 3 summarizes the performance of RuC1 catalyst in furfural hydrogenation under different hydrogen pressures. The results confirm the influence of pressure, with a significant improvement in conversion observed at 40 bar compared to 20 bar after 30 min (70% vs. near-complete conversion, entries 1 & 2). Optimal conversion to furfuryl alcohol with 98 % selectivity occurred after 30 min of reaction at 40 bar and 180 °C. The ideal reaction conditions were determined to be 180 °C, 40 bar pressure, no acid present, and a substrate/catalyst ratio of 3000/1. Entries 2 and 3 in Table 3 indicate that the production of the active species (Ru-H) is unaffected by acid, with temperature being a more crucial variable. Having established optimal reaction conditions for temperature, pressure, and acid usage, we investigated the impact of substrate concentration. As expected in homogeneous catalysis, conversion generally decreases with increasing substrate loading due to limited availability of active catalyst sites per substrate molecule. Table 4 summarizes the catalytic activity of the RuC1 and RuC2 catalysts in the furfural hydrogenation reaction as the catalyst substrate ratio increases from 3000/1 to 10,000/1 at 180 °C and 40 bar. Compared to the ideal 3000/1 ratio (Table 3), increasing the substrate concentration to 6000/1 resulted in a noticeable decrease in conversion for both catalysts RuC1 and RuC2. This is a typical behavior, as increasing the substrate concentration requires more time for the reaction to achieve maximum conversions. The catalysts remained active, achieving 98 % conversion to catalyst RuC1 and 96 % conversion to catalyst RuC2 after 2.5 and 3.0 h respectively using a substrate/catalyst ratio 10,000/1 (see entries 7 and 11 in Table 4). This demonstrates the robustness of these catalysts for furfural hydrogenation at high substrate concentrations. Encouraged by the success with furfural, we applied the optimized reaction conditions to hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation (Table 5 ). Both RuC1 and RuC2 displayed excellent activity, achieving high conversions even at a substrate/catalyst ratio of 6000/1. However, the reaction requires more reaction time to achieve 100 % conversion at higher substrate concentrations. When comparing the results of furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation under the same reaction conditions, it was found that furfural hydrogenation needs less reaction time to achieve 98 % conversion than hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation [21,22]. This suggests that hydroxymethylfurfural conversion might be kinetically slower than furfural, possibly due to the presence of an additional hydroxyl group that could hinder catalyst interaction. Our previous work explored furfural hydrogenation using ruthenium (II) complexes with phosphorus-nitrogen (PN) ligands achieving 99 % conversion but requiring longer reaction times than the ruthenium (II) complexes that contain nitrogen-phosphorus-nitrogen (NPN) ligands [17]. The complexes studied in this work showed similar activity in shorter reaction time and they are active with maximum substrate loads 10,000/1. In 30 min, the catalysts RuC1 and RuC2 were able to hydrogenate furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural with a substrate/catalyst ratio of 3000/1. They were able to achieve a 99 % conversion and high selectivity. The catalysts also demonstrated high activity at a substrate/catalyst ratio of 10,000/1, although the reaction required more reaction time. In homogeneous catalysis, the ligand plays two critical roles in the catalytic process: it modulates the catalyst's activity due to the ligand's donor effects and modulates the reaction's selectivity using steric effects. Due to the reductive conditions of the reaction medium- it is usual to observe the formation of a solid during the catalytic process, which could be a decomposition process of the catalyst. [17]. The ligands have the function of stabilizing the metal under reaction conditions to always maintain a homogeneous reaction. Tables 4 and 5 summarize the activities obtained using the RuC1 and RuC2 catalysts and compare the conversions obtained with the Ru(PPh3)3Cl2 catalyst. The results show that the RuC1 and RuC2 complexes are more active than the Ru(PPh3)3Cl2 precursor (Table 4 entry 14, Table 5 entry 17) in both catalytic reactions under similar reaction conditions. The catalysts are active without triphenylphosphine used as an secondary ligand, however after three hours of reaction, a decrease of activity was observed, probably due to the partial decomposition of the catalyst. In addition, when the catalysts were studied in the presence of a mole of triphenylphosphine as an secondary ligand, activities improved on average by 30 %. Several studies carried out by us show that the triphenylphosphine ligand has the function of stabilizing the catalyst under highly reducing medium [17,18,21]. This hypothesis was confirmed by the results obtained in Tables 4 and 5, which show that all activities improve in the presence of one mole of triphenylphosphine. The hydrogenation mechanism for ruthenium complexes is well known. An Ru-H species is formed initially through hydrogen's heterolytic or homolytic addition to the metal center, which acts as a catalyst (Ru-hydride complex) [17,19,20,22,48]. The donor effects of the ligands on the metal promote the formation of Ru-H as an active species in the hydrogenation reaction. Co-catalysts, typically organic or inorganic acids, are often used to form Ru-H. However, this fact could be complemented by increasing the temperature of the catalytic reaction. Ruthenium hydrides have been detected and characterized by our group using nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR). A characteristic multiple signals is typically observed between −10 and −14 ppm [17,19]. The temperature is a crucial factor in the performance of the catalyst studied here, since the activity improves significantly with increasing temperature from 150 °C to 180 °C, the temperature probably facilitates the activation of the molecular hydrogen forming a ruthenium hydride species (Ru-H). The results obtained suggest that under these conditions the use of the secondary ligand is crucial, since the catalyst could decompose. This conclusion is based on the fact that the conversion decreases when the secondary ligand was not used. The catalytic results obtained in this work allow us to conclude that it is possible to obtain biomass derivatives with high purity using low concentrations of catalyst. The derivatives of furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural can be used as biofuels or fuel additives in industry. Furanic compounds also have multiple industrial applications. These compounds, obtained from biomass derivatives, allow for a more environmentally friendly chemistry, reducing the use of fossil-based compounds [1]. 4 Conclusion Two ruthenium (II) catalysts (RuC1 and RuC2) containing a nitrogen-phosphorus-nitrogen ligand in their structure exhibited high activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural. The catalysts achieved over 96 % conversion in both catalytic reactions at 180 °C in 3 h or 4 h reaction times for furfural and hydroxymethyfurfural hydrogenation respectively, using a substrate/catalyst ratio of 10,000/1. The ligands provide donor effect to the metal improving the catalyst stability under reaction conditions. It was not possible to conclude that the -CH2- and -NH- used for linking the phosphine and polypyridine fragments of the NPN ligands have an effect on molecular hydrogen activation. The high substrate/catalyst ratios used in both catalytic reactions showed that the catalysts were very stable. This led to 96–99 % conversions with high selectivity. The conversions achieved are similar to those reported using heterogeneous catalysts. However, the homogeneous catalysts reported in this study are active even at substrate/catalyst ratios of 10,000/1. The results obtained suggest that ruthenium complexes containing NPN ligands could be used to obtain biomass derivatives with good yield. coredata.dc:description: This work describes the synthesis and evaluation as catalysts of two ruthenium(II) complexes, RuC1 and RuC2, containing NPN ligands=(N-(phenyl(pyridin-2-ylamino)phosphino)pyridin-2-amine and 2-((phenyl(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)phosphino)methyl)pyridine, respectively) for furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation. The catalysts displayed exceptional activity under mild conditions (180 °C, 40 bar H2) achieving over 98 % conversion and 98–99 % selectivity towards furfuryl alcohol (from furfural) and bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (from hydroxymethylfurfural) within 30 min, using a substrate-catalyst ratio of 3000:1. Remarkably, the catalysts maintained their efficacy even at a tenfold higher substrate loading (10,000:1), albeit with extended reaction times (3 and 4 h for furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural, respectively). Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were impressive, reaching 3920 h−1 and 3200 h−1 for furfural hydrogenation with the catalyst RuC1 and RuC2, respectively. Similarly, TOFs for hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenation were 2450 h−1 and 2475 h−1 for RuC1 and RuC2, respectively. Notably, the catalysts exhibited excellent stability under reaction conditions. These findings demonstrate the promising potential of RuC1 and RuC2 for efficient hydrogenation of biomass-derived furans, offering a sustainable approach for the production of valuable bio-based chemicals.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of sustainable chemicals and fuels from biomass derivatives using homogeneous ruthenium catalysts
